article.name: Phish Alert Button (PAB) Display Settings
article.title: Phish Alert Button (PAB) Display Settings
article.body:
This article shows admins how to customize the Phish Alert Button (PAB) display settings and provides visual examples of how these customizations will appear across different email platforms. By configuring these display options, admins can tailor the PAB's appearance, messaging, and user feedback to match their organization's requirements and branding standards across all supported email environments.

If you'd like additional information about the PAB, see our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.

Comments and Disposition

Click the tabs below to see how the Comments and Disposition Settings will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Comments and Disposition Settings interface, where admins configure the Phish Alert Button (PAB) label and description text that will appear in users' Email Classification section when they access the PAB.

Screenshot: The Comments and Disposition Settings interface, where admins configure the Phish Alert Button (PAB) label and description text that will appear in users' Email Classification section when they access the PAB.

Screenshot: The Comments and Disposition Settings interface, where admins configure the Phish Alert Button (PAB) label and description text that will appear in users' Email Classification section when they access the PAB.

Screenshot: The Comments and Disposition Settings interface, where admins configure the Phish Alert Button (PAB) label and description text that will appear in users' Email Classification section when they access the PAB.

Button Text

Click the tabs below to see how the Button Text setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Button Text setting field, where admins configure the text that will appear on the Phish Alert Button (PAB) when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Button Text setting field, where admins configure the text that will appear on the Phish Alert Button (PAB) when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Button Text setting field, where admins configure the text that will appear on the Phish Alert Button (PAB) when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Button Text setting field, where admins configure the text that will appear on the Phish Alert Button (PAB) when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Button Group Text

Click the tabs below to see how the Button Group Text setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Button Group Text input field, where admins configure the text that appears at the top-left corner of the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users click the PAB to report suspicious emails.

The Gmail versions of the PAB do not have Button Group Text.

Screenshot: The Button Group Text input field, where admins configure the text that appears at the top-left corner of the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users click the PAB to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Button Group Text input field, where admins configure the text that appears at the top-left corner of the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users click the PAB to report suspicious emails.

User Response Report non-simulated

Click the tabs below to see how this setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

User Response Report simulated

Click the tabs below to see how this setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

PAB Icon

Click the tabs below to see how the PAB icon will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Icon field, where admins upload the icon that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Icon field, where admins upload the icon that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Icon field, where admins upload the icon that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Confirmation Message

Click the tabs below to see how the Confirmation Message setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Confirmation Message field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Confirmation Message field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Confirmation Message field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Confirmation Message field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Forwarded Email Prefix

Click the tabs below to see how the Forward Email Prefix setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Forwarded Email Prefix field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Forwarded Email Prefix field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Forwarded Email Prefix field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Screenshot: The Forwarded Email Prefix field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

Ignore Training Notifications - Training Email Response

Click the tabs below to see how this setting will display for your PAB version.

Screenshot: The Response when the user reports a training email field, where admins configure the text that will appear in the Phish Alert Button (PAB) menu when users access it to report suspicious emails.

images.alt:
This image is a comparison showing the configuration settings (left) and the resulting user interface (right) for an email reporting tool (Phish Alert). An orange arrow highlights the direct mapping between specific configuration parameters and the end-user selectable options.

**Configuration Panel (Left, under "Comments and Disposition Settings"):**
*   **Phishing or Suspicious Label:** Input field contains the value "Phishing or Suspicious."
*   **Phishing or Suspicious Description:** Input field contains the value "I think this email is suspicious."
*   Below these are corresponding fields for "Spam or Junk" and "Unknown" labels and descriptions.

**User Interface Panel (Right, "Phish Alert" dialog):**
*   The dialog presents options for reporting a known email (Subject: "KnowBe4 Security Tips - How Secure is Your Mobile Device?").
*   Under the header **Email Classification,** a set of radio buttons are displayed.
*   The first option is selected, labeled **Phishing or Suspicious** (derived from the configuration Label), and includes the subtext **I think this email is suspicious** (derived from the configuration Description).
*   Other options include "Spam or Junk" and "Unknown," each with its corresponding description.
*   A "Report" button is present at the bottom for submission.

The image confirms that the text configured in the **Phishing or Suspicious Label** and **Phishing or Suspicious Description** fields directly controls the primary label and supporting subtext for the corresponding selection option presented to the end user.

The image illustrates the direct relationship between administrative configuration settings and the resulting end-user interface display for email classification reporting.

**Left Panel (Administrative Configuration):**
The panel, titled "Comments and Disposition Settings," displays input fields for customizing report labels and descriptions. The highlighted section defines the "Phishing or Suspicious" classification:

*   **Phishing or Suspicious Label:** Input field contains the text "Phishing or Suspicious."
*   **Phishing or Suspicious Description:** Input field contains the text "I think this email is suspicious."
*   **Control:** A blue toggle switch is active, indicating the option to "Display Phishing or Suspicious Description" is enabled.

**Right Panel (End-User Interface/Output):**
The compact UI, titled "Phish Alert," displays the report submission form. Under the header **EMAIL CLASSIFICATION**, the classification options are presented as radio buttons.

The active (selected) radio button corresponds directly to the settings configured on the left panel, concatenating the custom label and description into a single string displayed to the user:

*   **Display Text:** "Phishing or Suspicious - I think this email is suspicious."

The orange arrow visually confirms that the administrative inputs define the displayed text for the corresponding end-user selection option.
images.context: on section when they access the PAB.

images.alt:
This image displays a comparison between an administrative configuration panel (left) and a mobile application user interface (right), illustrating how custom settings are applied in a phishing reporting workflow.

**Left Panel (Configuration Settings):**

* **Header:** "Comments and Disposition Settings."
* **Section 1 (Phishing or Suspicious):**
    * **Phishing or Suspicious Label:** Input field showing "Phishing or Suspicious."
    * **Phishing or Suspicious Description:** Input field showing **"This email is a threat."** (Highlighted by an orange box).
    * **Toggle Switch:** Activated ("Display Phishing or Suspicious Description").
* **Other Sections:** Sections for "Spam or Junk" and "Unknown Label" follow, each with customizable labels, descriptions, and corresponding display toggles.

**Right Panel (Mobile Phish Alert UI):**

* **Context:** A mobile screen titled "Phish Alert."
* **Email Details:** Displays sender ("KnowBe4") and subject ("You've been enrolled in Computer Coach training!"). A blue "M365" button is visible.
* **Question:** "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
* **Email Classification Section:** Displays radio button options for classifying the email:
    * **Option 1 (Selected):** **"Phishing or Suspicious"** with the subtext **"This email is a threat."** (Highlighted by an orange box and an orange arrow connecting it to the configuration panel).
    * **Option 2:** "Spam or Junk" with subtext "This email is spam."
    * **Option 3:** "Unknown" with subtext "I'm not sure how to describe this email."
* **Comment Field:** A text area labeled "Add a comment..." with a character limit display (0/360).
* **Action Button:** A prominent blue button at the bottom labeled "Report."

**Technical Context:** The image demonstrates the direct mapping of custom disposition settings, specifically the "Phishing or Suspicious" label and its corresponding description ("This email is a threat."), from an administrative backend to the user-facing classification options within a mobile reporting tool.

This image illustrates the mapping of administrator-defined settings to an end-user mobile application UI, specifically concerning email classification and reporting.

**Left Pane (Configuration Panel):**
This section displays the "Comments and Disposition Settings" configuration interface.
*   **Phishing or Suspicious Label:** Defined fields allow customization of labels and descriptions for phishing reports.
*   **Highlighted Field:** The "Phishing or Suspicious Description" text box contains the value: **"This email is a threat."**
*   **Other Defined Labels:** Settings are also shown for "Spam or Junk" (Description: "I think this email is spam.") and "Unknown" (Description: "I'm not sure how to categorize this email."). Toggle switches are available to control the display of these descriptions.

**Right Pane (Mobile UI - Phish Alert Modal):**
The right pane shows a mobile application interface ("Phish Alert") used for reporting an email (Sender: KnowBe4, Subject: Important: Security Awareness Training).
*   **Section:** "Email Classification:"
*   **Classification Options:** Three radio buttons are presented.
*   **Selected Option:** The **"Phishing or Suspicious"** radio button is selected (checked).
*   **Description Mapping:** Directly beneath the selected label, the text is displayed: **"This email is a threat."** This text block is highlighted and connected via an orange arrow to the corresponding input field in the configuration panel (Left Pane).

**Context and Function:**
The image demonstrates that the customizable description text entered in the administrative "Phishing or Suspicious Description" field is rendered directly below the corresponding radio button selection within the end-user's "Email Classification" modal. The user can then proceed with the report using the blue "Report" button at the bottom.
images.context: tion when they access the PAB.

images.alt:
This image illustrates the relationship between a configuration setting (left) and the resulting user interface element (right) within a phishing alert system, likely associated with KnowBe4.

**Configuration Panel (Left):**
The left half displays language and message customization settings under the header "Languages," specifically for "English (United States) (Default)." Key settings include:
1.  **Forwarded Email Prefix:** Configured as `[Phish Alert]`.
2.  **Confirmation Message:** Set to "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?".
3.  **Button Text:** Configured as "Report" (highlighted).
4.  **Button Group Text:** Set to "KnowBe4".

**Phish Alert Dialog (Right):**
The right half displays the resulting live user interface, a modal window titled "Phish Alert," which includes KnowBe4 branding and an "M365" badge. This dialog features:
1.  **Confirmation Text:** Mirroring the configuration: "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?".
2.  **Subject Display:** "KnowBe4 Security Tips - How Secure is Your Mobile Device?".
3.  **Email Classification Section:** Radio buttons are present, with "Phishing or Suspicious" selected.
4.  **Action Button:** The configured **Report** button is prominently displayed in blue at the bottom of the dialog (highlighted).

**Mapping:**
An orange arrow visually connects the input field "Button Text: Report" in the configuration panel to the functional blue "Report" button in the Phish Alert dialog, demonstrating the direct application of the backend setting to the user-facing interface.
images.context: ill display for your PAB version.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration screen juxtaposed with a functional user interface (UI) element, illustrating the mapping between configuration settings and the live application display.

**Left Panel (Configuration Settings):**

This panel, titled "Languages," configures language-specific settings for the Phish Alert tool. Key visible fields include:

*   **Language:** Set to "English (United States) (Default)."
*   **Forwarded Email Prefix:** Input field contains `[Phish Alert]`.
*   **Confirmation Message:** Input field contains `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`
*   **Button Text (Configuration Source):** An input field labeled "Button Text" contains the value `Report`.
*   **Button Group Text:** An adjacent input field contains the value `KnowBe4`.

**Right Panel (Phish Alert Sidebar UI):**

This panel represents the live user interface for reporting an email via the "Phish Alert" tool (associated with KnowBe4 Inc.).

*   **Header:** Title is "Phish Alert."
*   **Confirmation Prompt:** Displays the configured "Confirmation Message."
*   **Email Details:** Displays "SUBJECT: Time Stamp Notification" and a button "Show Sender's Details."
*   **EMAIL CLASSIFICATION:** A radio button group with three options, where the first option is selected: "Phishing or Suspicious - I think this email is suspicious."
*   **Action Button (UI Destination):** A prominent blue action button at the bottom of the sidebar displays the text `Report`.

**Mapping Relationship:**

An orange arrow visually connects the "Button Text" input field (value: `Report`) in the configuration panel directly to the final blue action button (text: `Report`) in the Phish Alert sidebar, confirming that this configuration field dictates the button label in the end-user interface.

images.alt:
This image illustrates the linkage between an administrative configuration setting and the resulting end-user interface text in a mobile application, specifically for a phishing reporting tool.

**Left Pane (Configuration Interface):**
This section displays language customization settings under the header **Languages**. The "English (United States) (Default)" language profile is shown, detailing parameters such as:
1.  **Forwarded Email Prefix:** Input field set to `[Phish Alert]`.
2.  **Confirmation Message:** Text area set to `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`
3.  **Button Text:** Input field containing the value `Report`.
4.  **Button Group Text:** Input field containing the value `KnowBe4`.

**Right Pane (Mobile Client Interface):**
This simulates a mobile application screen titled **Phish Alert**. It presents a user flow for classifying and reporting a potential phishing email. Key elements include:
1.  **Confirmation Text:** `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`
2.  **Email Classification:** A radio button selection group with three options: **Phishing or Suspicious** (selected), **Spam or Junk**, and **Unknown**.
3.  **Comment Field:** A text area labeled `Add a comment...` with a character limit counter (0/360).
4.  **Primary Action Button:** A full-width, solid blue button located at the bottom edge of the screen.

**Technical Correlation (Arrow):**
An orange directional arrow highlights the direct mapping between the configurable **Button Text** input field (`Report`) on the administrative interface (left) and the text displayed on the primary action button (`Report`) within the mobile application's reporting screen (right). This demonstrates the platform’s localization and UI text customization capabilities.

This image illustrates the direct mapping between configuration settings and a resulting mobile application UI for a Phish Alert reporting tool.

**Left Panel (Configuration/Admin Interface):**

This section details the language configuration settings for the reporting tool.

*   **Language Settings:** The interface is currently configured for "English (United States) (Default)."
*   **Forwarded Email Prefix:** Configured value is `[Phish Alert]`.
*   **Confirmation Message:** Configured value is `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`.
*   **Button Text (Key Parameter):** The input field value for the primary action button is explicitly set to `Report`.
*   **Button Group Text:** Configured value is `KnowBe4`.

**Right Panel (Mobile Application Interface):**

This screen depicts the end-user interface displayed on a smartphone (iOS context evident by the status bar). The screen title is **Phish Alert**.

*   **Context/Source:** Displays `KnowBe4` (matching the Button Group Text) and an `M365` tag.
*   **Confirmation Prompt:** The displayed prompt, `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`, directly reflects the configured Confirmation Message.
*   **Subject:** `Important: Security Awareness Training`.
*   **Email Classification:** Provides three radio button options:
    1.  **Phishing or Suspicious** (Selected)
    2.  **Spam or Junk**
    3.  **Unknown**
*   **Comment Field:** A text area is available for input, labeled "Add a comment..." (limit 360 characters).
*   **Primary Action Button:** A full-width, blue primary action button is located at the bottom of the screen.

**Linkage:**

An orange arrow highlights the direct functional connection: the administrative setting for **Button Text** (`Report`) dictates the text displayed on the **Primary Action Button** (`Report`) in the user's mobile interface.

The image displays a user interface split between language configuration settings (left panel) and a dynamic preview of the "Phish Alert" end-user dialog (right panel).

**Configuration Panel (Left):**
Under the **Languages** section for "English (United States) (Default)," key text fields are visible:
1.  **Forwarded Email Prefix:** Configured as `[Phish Alert]`.
2.  **Confirmation Message:** Configured as `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`.
3.  **Button Text:** Configured as `Report`.
4.  **Button Group Text:** Configured as `KnowBe4`.

**Dialog Preview (Right):**
The "Phish Alert" dialog shows the user interaction interface. An orange arrow and bounding boxes illustrate a direct link between the **Button Group Text** configuration field (`KnowBe4`) and the display text shown in the header of the dialog, adjacent to the "M365" badge.

The dialog content includes:
*   **Subject:** `KnowBe4 Security Tips - How Secure is Your Mobile Device?`
*   **Email Classification:** Radio button group with **Phishing or Suspicious** selected.
*   **Action Button:** A blue primary action button labeled **Report**.

This image compares a security software's administrative language configuration settings (left) with the resulting end-user display on a mobile application (right).

**Left Pane (Language Configuration UI):**
This section displays settings for the "English (United States) (Default)" language profile. Key fields and their values include:
*   **Forwarded Email Prefix:** `[Phish Alert]`
*   **Confirmation Message:** `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`
*   **Button Text:** `Report`
*   **Button Group Text:** `KnowBe4` (Highlighted in an orange box.)

**Right Pane (Mobile Application UI - Phish Alert):**
The mobile interface, titled "Phish Alert," displays the confirmation dialog utilizing the configured text:
*   The header displays the text configured in the 'Button Group Text' field: **KnowBe4** (Highlighted in an orange box), positioned above the confirmation query.
*   A blue label/tag displaying **M365** is located opposite the branding text.
*   The confirmation text matches the configuration: *“Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?”*
*   The interface allows the user to classify the email via radio buttons, with **"Phishing or Suspicious"** currently selected.
*   The action button at the bottom of the screen displays the configured 'Button Text': **Report**.

An orange arrow visually connects the 'Button Group Text' configuration input (`KnowBe4`) directly to its corresponding rendered position (`KnowBe4`) in the mobile application header, demonstrating the localization of the branding text.

This image illustrates the functional mapping between a back-end localization configuration panel and its corresponding display on a mobile application interface.

**Configuration Panel (Left):**
The panel displays language settings (English (United States)) for an email reporting tool. Key configurable fields include:
*   **Forwarded Email Prefix:** `[Phish Alert]`
*   **Confirmation Message:** `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?`
*   **Button Text:** `Report`
*   **Button Group Text:** `KnowBe4` (This field is highlighted as the source of dynamic text.)

**Mobile Application UI (Right):**
The right side displays an iOS-style modal dialog titled "Phish Alert" for email classification.
*   **Mapped Text:** The text **KnowBe4** appears prominently in the dialog header, linked directly by an orange arrow to the **Button Group Text** configuration field.
*   **Contextual Text:** The confirmation message `Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?` is displayed below the mapped text.
*   **Action Elements:** The primary action button at the bottom is labeled **Report**, consistent with the Button Text configuration.
*   **Classification:** The dialog allows users to select an Email Classification (e.g., "Phishing or Suspicious," "Spam or Junk").

**Context:** The illustration demonstrates how administrative text configured in the "Button Group Text" setting is rendered as a primary textual identifier within the user-facing mobile "Phish Alert" notification dialog.

The image displays a security software configuration interface alongside a resultant end-user notification, demonstrating the relationship between administrative settings and user feedback.

**Configuration Panel (Left):**
The panel, titled **Phishing Settings**, presents options for customizing responses when users report suspicious emails.

1.  **Non-Simulated Response:** A toggle is enabled for "Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email." The associated text box contains the following customized confirmation message: "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"
2.  **Simulated Response:** A toggle is enabled for "Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email," with the congratulatory text: "Congratulations! The email you reported was a simulated phishing attack initiated by your company. Good job!"
3.  **Response Duration:** The field is set to **3 seconds**.

**User Alert Dialog (Right):**
A modal dialog box titled **Phish Alert** is overlaid on a background environment (likely an email client). This dialog represents the end-user experience upon reporting a non-simulated threat.

The dialog content displays the exact text configured in the "non-simulated" setting: "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!" The dialog includes an **Ok** button for user acknowledgment.

**Contextual Link:**
An orange arrow highlights and connects the configured text within the "Phishing Settings" text box to the identical text displayed within the live "Phish Alert" pop-up, illustrating the direct implementation of the administrative feedback message.

This image displays a configuration process demonstrating the user-facing result of a defined text template within an anti-phishing system.

**Administrative Interface (Left Panel):**
The "Phishing Settings" panel shows configuration options.
1.  **Non-Simulated Response:** A toggle is active for "Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email." The custom response text is entered in a field below: *"Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"*
2.  **Simulated Response:** A separate active toggle and text box define the response for a reported phishing security test email.
3.  **Response Duration:** Set to "3 seconds."

**User Interface (Right Panel):**
A Knowledge Base/KnowBe4 Inc. "Phish Alert" client-side notification window appears over an email client.
1.  **Status:** The heading reads "Email Reported Successfully."
2.  **Response Display:** An orange arrow connects the text configured in the administrative interface (Non-Simulated Response) directly to the user's success notification screen. The text displayed is: *"Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"*
3.  **User Instruction:** The notification concludes with *"Refresh this page and return to your inbox."*

The image clearly illustrates that the content defined in the administrative "non-simulated" response template is rendered exactly in the corresponding user alert pop-up following a successful email report.
images.context: ccess it to report suspicious emails.

images.alt:
This image illustrates the linkage between an administrative "Phishing Settings" configuration panel and the resulting end-user display on a mobile device.

**Configuration Panel (Left):**
The panel contains settings for automated responses upon a user reporting a potential phishing email.

1.  **Non-Simulated Response:** A toggle is active for "Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email." The corresponding customizable text field contains the message: "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"
2.  **Simulated Response:** A separate active toggle controls the response for "Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email." The associated text reads: "Congratulations! The email you reported was a simulated phishing attack initiated by your company. Good job!"
3.  **Duration Control:** A numerical input field labeled "Response Duration" is set to "3 seconds."

**Mobile Preview (Right):**
A representation of a mobile application interface (Android style) displays the resulting user message. The content matches the customized text defined for the non-simulated report scenario, emphasizing the direct correlation between the configuration setting and the user experience.

*   **Message Text:** "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"
*   **UI Elements:** The screen includes a top status bar (showing time 19:03), a navigation bar with a close 'X' icon, and a full-width, primary action button labeled "Ok" at the bottom.

This image illustrates the configuration of automated user responses for reporting phishing emails, demonstrating the mapping from a configuration panel to the resulting mobile display.

**Left Panel (Configuration Interface):**

*   **Header:** "Phishing Settings".
*   **Section 1: Non-Simulated Phishing Response:**
    *   **Toggle/Label:** "Show a response when the user reports a non-simulated phishing email." (Toggle is active/blue).
    *   **Text Field (Highlighted in orange):** Contains the response message: "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"
*   **Section 2: Simulated Phishing Response:**
    *   **Toggle/Label:** "Show a response when the user reports a phishing security test email." (Toggle is active/blue).
    *   **Text Field:** Contains the response message: "Congratulations! The email you reported was a simulated phishing attack initiated by your company. Good job!"
*   **Response Duration:**
    *   **Label:** "Response Duration"
    *   **Input Field:** Contains the value "3" followed by the unit "seconds".

**Right Panel (Simulated Mobile Display):**

*   **Device Context:** A smartphone screen displaying an in-app browser or embedded web view.
*   **Status Bar (Top):** Displays time "19:41" and connectivity/battery icons (including "App Store" and "SOS").
*   **Navigation Bar:** Contains a back arrow `<` and a domain displayed as "eu.pab.knowbe4.com".
*   **Content Area (Response Display):**
    *   The text displayed matches the configured message for a non-simulated email report: "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!" (This content is highlighted by an orange box, matching the highlighted configuration field).
*   **Footer:** A blue button labeled "Ok".

**Relationship:**

An orange arrow visually connects the configured text field in the "Phishing Settings" panel (left) to the actual displayed message on the smartphone screen (right), confirming that the text specified for reporting a non-simulated email is the content rendered to the end-user.

The image displays a split view demonstrating a Security Awareness platform's configuration settings juxtaposed with a live user notification within an email client (likely Microsoft Outlook).

**UI Context: Configuration Panel (Left)**

The **"Phishing Settings"** panel configures automated user responses upon reporting emails. Key elements include:

1.  **Non-Simulated Phishing Response:** A toggle switch is enabled, allowing a customized response for genuine threat reports.
    *   *Text configured:* "Thank you for reporting this email to your security team. People like you are the reason our company is more secure!"
2.  **Simulated Phishing Test Response:** A toggle switch is enabled, allowing a customized response for successful identification of test emails.
    *   *Text configured:* **"Congratulations! The email you reported was a simulated phishing attack initiated by your company. Good job!"**
3.  **Response Duration:** A numeric input field sets the display time for the alert, configured to **"3 seconds."**

**UI Context: Live User Alert (Right)**

A modal dialog, titled **"Phish Alert,"** overlays the email client interface. An orange arrow highlights the direct correspondence between the configured text and the displayed alert text.

1.  **Alert Content:** The text within the modal exactly matches the configured response for a reported simulated phishing test email: **"Congratulations! The email you reported was a simulated phishing attack initiated by your company. Good job!"**
2.  **Action Button:** A blue **"Ok"** button confirms the alert.

**Context:** The image technically illustrates the successful reporting of a simulated phishing attack by an end-user, triggering the predetermined congratulatory response defined within the system's configuration settings.

This text is emphasized by an orange bounding box.

**2. User Interface Notification Panel (Right):**

*   **Context:** The header indicates a utility named "KnowBe4 Inc. Success." The main heading is "Email Reported Successfully."

This image displays two interconnected views of a security awareness platform's User Interface (UI): a configuration settings panel and a live email reporting sidebar.

**I. Configuration Panel (Left Side)**

The left side details administrative settings for a "Phishing Alert Button (PAB)."

*   **PAB Version:** Set to "Hybrid PAB," with a "Set as Default" action button.
*   **Key Fields:** "Setting Name" and "License Key" are present (content is obscured).
*   **Email Format:** Two radio buttons allow selection between "EML" (currently selected) and "MSG."
*   **Icon Customization (Highlighted):** A section labeled "Icon" provides an input field to customize the PAB visual identifier. The input text reads "Choose a file or drop it here..." and is accompanied by a "Browse" button. The representative icon displayed is an envelope containing a document, pierced by a fishing hook.
*   **Toggle Options (Partial View):** Configuration settings are controlled by toggle switches, including "Limit CRID Validation," "Enable Microsoft 365 Defender Integration," and an active toggle for "Ignore Training Notifications."

**II. Phish Alert Sidebar (Right Side)**

The right side displays a "Phish Alert" reporting sidebar, likely within an Outlook or Microsoft 365 environment (indicated by the "New Outlook" toggle at the top).

*   **Icon Correspondence (Highlighted):** The orange arrow connects the customizable icon field in the settings panel to the live "Phish Alert" button/icon located in the sidebar header, confirming the element being configured.
*   **Header:** The sidebar is titled "Phish Alert" and features the security icon (envelope/hook).
*   **Context:** The report is initiated for an email from "KnowBe4" (tagged M365).
*   **Confirmation Text:** "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
*   **Subject:** "Your Daily SecurityCoach Summary."
*   **Email Classification:** Users classify the reported email using radio buttons:
    *   **Selected:** "Phishing or Suspicious" ("This email is a threat.").
    *   **Unselected:** "Spam or Junk" ("This email is spam.").
    *   **Unselected:** "Unknown."
*   **Comment Field:** An "Add a comment..." text area is available (capacity 0/360).

images.alt:
The image displays two linked components of a security awareness platform, demonstrating the customization of the Phish Alert Button (PAB) icon and its resulting appearance in an end-user interface.

**I. Configuration Panel (Left Side):**

This section presents a backend configuration form for the security tool, titled "Select PAB Version" (currently set to **Hybrid PAB**). Key UI elements include:

*   **Setting Name and License Key:** Standard text input fields (content blurred).
*   **Email Format:** Radio button selection between **EML** (selected) and **MSG**.
*   **Icon Customization:** A dedicated configuration block labeled **Icon**. This area allows for uploading or dropping a file to define the PAB visual identity.
    *   **UI:** A drop zone with the prompt "Choose a file or drop it here..." and a **Browse** button.
    *   **Placeholder Visual:** The input box contains a graphical representation of the custom icon: an envelope with a fishing hook descending over it.
*   **Feature Toggles:** A list of configurable options, including **Limit CRID Validation** (Off), **Ignore Training Notifications** (On), and various integrations/formatting settings (all other shown toggles are Off).

**II. Phish Alert Modal (Right Side):**

This is an end-user modal displayed within a webmail client (indicated by the Google UI context). It is the recipient of the customization configured in the left panel.

*   **Header:** **Phish Alert**.
*   **Custom Icon Placement:** The **customized envelope/hook icon** from the configuration panel is prominently displayed next to the product branding.
*   **Branding/Context:** **KnowBe4 Inc.** with the subtext **Report Email**.
*   **Prompt:** A confirmation question: "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
*   **Email Summary:** Displays the email subject: **Time Stamp Notification**.
*   **Action Button:** **Show Sender's Details**.
*   **Email Classification:** A required radio selection for categorization:
    1.  **Phishing or Suspicious** (Selected).
    2.  **Spam or Junk**.
    3.  **Unknown**.
*   **Input Field:** A text area for optional user comments.
*   **Primary Action:** A solid blue button labeled **Report**.

**Contextual Relationship (Orange Arrow):**

The orange arrow explicitly links the Icon customization upload area (Configuration Panel) to the specific instance of the custom icon displayed within the live **Phish Alert** end-user modal, illustrating the direct effect of the administrative setting.

The key element is the input field labeled **"Forwarded Email Prefix"**, which is set to the value `[Phish Alert]`. Other visible configuration fields include "Confirmation Message" and "Button Text."

The right side displays an email client interface (resembling Outlook), showing an Inbox list and an open email message. Orange arrows connect the configuration prefix to the resulting text:

1.  **Inbox List View:** The subject line of a reported email in the inbox pane is prefixed by the configured value: `[Phish Alert] SecurityCoach Admin Notifications Enabled`. The prefix is highlighted with a gray bounding box.
2.  **Email Reading Pane:** The subject line of the open email message also displays the configuration prefix, `[Phish Alert]`, immediately followed by the original subject line (`SecurityCoach Admin Notifications Enabled`).

**Context:** The image demonstrates that setting the "Forwarded Email Prefix" in the administrator console dictates the prefix text applied to the subject line of security-related emails (e.g., reports of phishing emails) when they are forwarded or processed by the system.
